Preliminaries
Introductory text. To do.
Regular rooted tree groups
true or false
Groups acting on the regular rooted trees T_{k,n} are stored together with their degree k\in\mathbb{N}_{\ge 2} (see ) and depth n\in\mathbb{N} (see ) as well as other attributes and properties in this category.
The degree of G.
The argument of this attribute is a regular rooted tree group G.
gap> RegularRootedTreeGroupDegree(AutT(2,3)); 2
The depth of G.
The argument of this attribute is a regular rooted tree group G.
gap> RegularRootedTreeGroupDepth(AutT(2,3)); 3
The regular rooted tree group G as an object of the category , together with its degree k (see ) and its depth n (see ).
The arguments of this method are a permutation group G \le\mathrm{Aut}(T_{k,n}), its degree k and its depth n.
Auxiliary functions
The restriction of aut to the subtree below the level 1 vertex i, as an element of \mathrm{Aut}(T_{k,n-1}).
The arguments of this function are a degree k \in\mathbb{N}_{\ge 2}, a depth n \in\mathbb{N}, an element aut of \mathrm{Aut}(T_{k,n}) (see ), and a depth 1 vertex i \in\{1,\cdots,k\} of T_{k,n}.
gap> BelowAction(2,2,(1,2)(3,4),2); (1,2)
Removes G-conjugates from the list subgroups.
The arguments of this function are a group, G, and a list subgroups of subgroups of G.
gap> G:=SymmetricGroup(3); Sym( [ 1 .. 3 ] ) gap> subgroups:=[Group((1,2)),Group((2,3)),Group((1,3))]; [ Group([ (1,2) ]), Group([ (2,3) ]), Group([ (1,3) ]) ] gap> RemoveConjugates(G,subgroups); gap> subgroups; [ Group([ (1,2) ]) ]
